tossups.question: The lonely speaker walks in the snow and remarks, “I have it in me… To scare myself with” these places in a poem by Robert Frost. The speaker of another poem notes “The darkness drops again” after envisioning one of these places with the “Reel shadows of the indignant… birds.” The speaker sees a “naked, bestial” creature eating its own “bitter” heart in a poem titled for one of these places by Stephen Crane. W. B. Yeats’s (“yates’s”) “The (*) Second Coming” contains the image of a creature “moving its slow thighs” in one of these places. A “colossal Wreck” with a “wrinkled lip” and “sneer of cold command” is found in one of these places near a pedestal with the phrase “Look on my works, ye Mighty and despair!” For 10 points, “a traveller from an antique land” in Percy Shelley’s poem “Ozymandias” describes a ruined sculpture found in what sort of place?
tossups.answer: deserts [accept “Desert Places” or “In the Desert”; accept arid land or sand; prompt on wasteland] <NC, Poetry>

tossups.question: After this group of buildings was completed, one of their robing rooms was filled with frescoes modeled on the art of Pinturicchio (“peen-too-REEK-yo”) by William Dyce. The architect of these buildings used a similar steep, steel roof in his design for Halifax Town Hall. The interiors of these buildings were modeled on sketches by the historian Augustus Pugin (“PYEW-jin”). Charles Barry designed these buildings in the (*) Gothic Revival style. The “effects of fog” on these buildings are shown with strokes of blue, purple, and orange in a series by Claude Monet. A tower in these buildings was renamed the Elizabeth Tower in 2012, and is currently silent due to ongoing renovations. Big Ben is part of, for 10 points, what set of buildings along the River Thames (“tems”) that house the British legislature?
tossups.answer: Houses of Parliament [or Palace of Westminster; or Westminster Palace; prompt on palace or parliament or British parliament or Westminster or buildings of parliament] <WA, Other Arts: Architecture>

tossups.question: A practitioner of one of this ethnic group’s traditional religions prevented a sheriff from testifying against him in court by chewing roots and was nicknamed “Dr. Buzzard.” Sterling Stuckey studied how 20th-century traditions among this ethnic group incorporated the “ring shout.” Due to its frequent use of healing roots, a religious tradition among this ethnic group was also called “conjure” or (*) “rootwork.” A song originated by these people states “I looked over Jordan, and what did I see?” Many of these people once practiced an animist religion called hoodoo. A call-and-response song created by these people has the refrain “coming for to carry me home.” For 10 points, identify these people who created “Swing Low, Sweet Chariot” and many other spirituals.
tossups.answer: African-Americans [prompt on slaves or black slaves or black people or African slaves or Gullah people; do not accept or prompt on just “Africans”] <JM, Religion>

tossups.question: This general received 30 percent of ticket sales from his contract with the film company Mutual to take reels of his troops in action. After this general seized a supply train, he filled it with thousands of his troops and had it enter a border town at night, allowing him to take the city. This general’s Conventionist army was massacred by Constitutionalist troops in trenches at the Battle of Celaya (“seh-LA-ya”). This general was killed in (*) 1923, probably on orders of Alvaro Obregón (“oh-breh-GOHN”), who earlier fought this man on behalf of Venustiano Carranza (“kah-RAHN-sah”). After this man raided Columbus, New Mexico, he eluded John Pershing’s troops in the Sonoran Desert. For 10 points, name this commander of the Division del Norte, a prominent Mexican revolutionary often characterized as a bandito.
tossups.answer: Pancho Villa [or Francisco Villa] <JM, World History>

tossups.question: These proteins are inhibited by aphidicolin (“uh-FID-uh-CO-leen”). MDA uses one of these proteins isolated from phi-29. Casposons encode a B family of these proteins, one of which was extracted from P. furiosus. They’re not antibodies, but the lambda and mu forms of these proteins participate in VDJ recombination. PCNA is a clamp protein that improves the processivity of these proteins. One form of these proteins has (*) bi-directional exonuclease activity for proofreading. These proteins, which are initially recruited to Ori (“OR-ee”) sites, synthesize Okazaki fragments on the lagging strand. By cleaving a pyrophosphate group off of an incoming dNTP, these proteins create products in the 5-prime to 3-prime direction. For 10 points, name these proteins that synthesize DNA.
tossups.answer: DNA polymerases [prompt on polymerase until “DNA” is read, but accept after] <EM, Biology: Genetics/Cell>

tossups.question: This theory’s equations are rewritten in terms of vectors that are typically denoted l, n, m, and m-bar in the tetrad formalism. Maximally symmetric solutions within this theory in which the vacuum energy density is positive are named for Willem de Sitter (“VILL-um duh SIT-tur”). This theory accurately predicted a shift of 1.75 arcseconds in the apparent position of the Hyades (“HY-uh-deez”) cluster during a solar eclipse. When expressed in geometric units, an equation central to this theory has a term of eight pi times the (*) stress-energy tensor. This theory has ten central field equations and maintains conservation of energy and momentum while describing the curvature of four-dimensional spacetime. For 10 points, name this theory of gravity formulated by Albert Einstein, which has a “special” counterpart.
tossups.answer: general relativity [or GR; prompt on relativity; do not accept or prompt on “gravity” or “gravitation”] <WA, Physics>

tossups.question: A poem in one of this author’s novels calls the title character “Wanted, wanted” and ends by stating “And the rest is rust and stardust.” This author wrote about a man who envisions a “white fountain” while reading a poem titled for a line from Timon of Athens. One of this author’s protagonists hands over a death sentence resembling T. S. Eliot’s “Ash Wednesday” before shooting his nemesis; the childhood love of that protagonist dies of typhus and is named for Edgar Allan Poe’s poem (*) “Annabel Lee.” In a novel by this author, the line “I was the shadow of the waxwing slain” opens a 999-line poem by John Shade. The playwright Clare Quilty pursues this author’s best-known character, the 12-year-old Dolores Haze. For 10 points, what author wrote about the pedophile Humbert Humbert’s love for a “nymphet” in his novel Lolita?
tossups.answer: Vladimir Nabokov <RK, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: An article by this academic in Health Affairs claimed that 40 percent of bankruptcies were caused by medical issues. After testifying against amending the US bankruptcy code in 2005, this thinker was called “mildly demagogic” by Joe Biden. This thinker, who put forth “A Plan for Economic Patriotism,” lambasted those who call parenting a “lifestyle choice” in her book The (*) Two-Income Trap. She proposed the creation of an agency implemented by the Dodd–Frank Act, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, while serving as a professor at Harvard Law School. In 2012, this thinker was elected to the Senate when she defeated Scott Brown. For 10 points, name this progressive Senator from Massachusetts and 2020 presidential candidate.
tossups.answer: Elizabeth Warren <WA, Other Academic>

tossups.question: Ross Cramer designed an artwork in this medium that shows a man with a bulging stomach and asks “Would you be more careful if it was you that got pregnant?” Another of these artworks prominently displays the word SOLD beneath Honest Gil Fulbright. A black-and-white photo of a model’s face is split into halves of positive and negative exposure in one of these artworks created by Barbara Kruger that displays the words “your (*) body is a battleground.” In 2008, the activist who founded OBEY clothing created one of these artworks in red, white, and blue whose variants showed the words “progress” and “change” under the face of a then-Senator from Illinois. For 10 points, give this sort of artwork exemplified by Shephard Fairey’s iconic piece that shows the word “HOPE” next to Barack Obama’s face.
tossups.answer: posters [accept political posters or campaign posters; prompt on ads or advertisements or political ads or prints or screen prints or graphics] <WA, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: One holder of this title paid an army of mercenaries 70 pieces of silver to kill 70 people in order to gain it. A poem authored by another person with this title describes a woman giving a general some curdled milk before crushing his head with a tent peg. A third person with this title promised to sacrifice the first thing that ever came out of his house, resulting in the sacrifice of his (*) daughter. A man with this title had his troops smash clay jars and blow shofars in order to panic a Midianite army. Abimelek and Jephthah held this title, as did the namesake of a group that distributes free Bibles to hotel rooms across America. The book of Ruth is preceded by a book titled for holders of, for 10 points, what title held by such leaders of Israel as Deborah and Gideon?
tossups.answer: Judges [or Shophetim] (The second clue refers to Deborah.) <JM, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: In a story by this author, a father says “in a surprised voice, ‘Shore-less seas’” as he begins to quote from Joaquin (“wah-KEEN”) Miller’s poem “Columbus.” One of this author’s protagonists is called “only a girl” after she impulsively lets the horse Flora escape before her father can kill it to feed to foxes. A story by this author centers on a woman who reflects on her divorce and her children Nichola and Judith while visiting her dying father and going to a (*) planetarium. This author of “Boys and Girls” wrote about a piano recital held by Miss Marsalles, at which a girl who is disabled performs a beautiful rendition of the title Gluck piece, in her story “The Dance of the Happy Shades.” “The Moons of Jupiter” was written by, for 10 points, what Canadian author of short fiction who won the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature?
tossups.answer: Alice Munro <RK, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: A young Claude Debussy was “crushed” by living in this city after writing a cantata, though he completed the vibrant suite Printemps (“pran-TOM”) in this city. Berlioz left this city to kill his ex, and wrote the cantata Herminie (“air-mee-NEE”) in one of four attempts to live in this city. Half the cellos tune their lowest string down to B to play faint marching tritones before a slithery English horn solo right after a nocturne set in this city fades out a phonograph recording of a chirping (*) nightingale. In 1913, Lili Boulanger (“boo-lawn-ZHAY”) was the first woman to win a prestigious French scholarship named for this city. A tone poem trilogy set in this city depicts four “festivals,” and certain objects in the Janiculum (“juh-NICK-yoo-lum”), a catacomb, and the Villa Borghese (“bor-GAY-zay”). Ottorino Respighi (“res-PEE-ghee”) depicted the “Pines” of, for 10 points, what city’s Appian Way?
tossups.answer: Rome [or Roma; accept Prix de Rome, Pines of Rome, Pini di Roma, Roman Festivals, or Feste Romane] <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: A formazen dye of this color is a reduction product of MTT used to detect metabolism. Basophilic features appear this color under an H and E stain. Solutions of pure buckminsterfullerene appear this color. The reaction of primary or secondary amines (“uh-MEENS”) with ninhydrin forms a pigment of this color named for Ruhemann (“ROO-uh-mon”). A dye of this color is displaced by a safranin counterstain in organisms with a thin (*) peptidoglycan layer. A pigment of this color stains cells in a clonogenic assay and to classify bacteria in a Gram stain; that pigment’s name includes “crystal” and this color. At standard temperature and pressure, iodine appears as a solid of this color. For 10 points, give this color of potassium permanganate.
tossups.answer: purple [or violet; accept crystal violet or Ruhemann’s purple] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: Transportation around this territory is provided by a company named for a local variety of boat, the Umiaq (“OO-mee-ahk”) Line. One percent of this territory’s population used to live in an apartment complex called Blok P, which was covered in a giant mural of this territory’s flag until its demolition in 2012. About 70 percent of this territory’s electricity comes from renewable energy, with over half from hydropower stations, such as one near its towns of Narsaq and Qaqortoq. This territory has its own parliament, the (*) Inatsisartut (“ee-not-SEE-sar-toot”), but recognizes Margarethe II (“mar-guh-REH-tuh the second”) as its sovereign. This territory, which was given a misleading name by Leif Erikson to encourage settlement, is now an autonomous subnational country governed from Nuuk. For 10 points, name this Danish territory, a large island near the Arctic.
tossups.answer: Greenland [or Kalaallit Nunaat or Grønland] <WA, Geography>

tossups.question: These groups were outraged when they were held to be liable at common law for some monetary losses in the Taff Vale case. Keir Hardie, who was known for his iconic tweed suit, led one of these groups before entering Parliament. A series of actions by these groups was labeled by James Callahan using a quote from the play Richard III. These groups issued many demands during that period, the (*) Winter of Discontent. Arthur Scargill was a leader of these groups who often clashed with Margaret Thatcher’s government. Ramsay MacDonald came from a party founded by leaders of these groups, which displaced the Liberals as Britain’s main left-leaning party. The historical backbone of the Labour Party was, for 10 points, what groups that bargain collectively on behalf of workers?
tossups.answer: British trade unions [or labour unions; accept any specific type of union; prompt on organized labor; prompt on garbage collectors by asking “what sort of group of garbage collectors?”] <WA, European History>

tossups.question: A book by Oxford historian Stephanie Dalley posits that this location was actually hundreds of miles to the north of where it is traditionally placed. Berossus is the earliest historical source to mention this location, which was built in his original hometown. Sources frequently named this location after Queen Semiramis (“seh-MEER-uh-miss”), who actually lived at least 200 years before its construction. According to Strabo, an early version of Archimedes’ (*) Screw was built for use at this location. Archaeologists have yet to find this place, whose name refers to the trees that drooped over its terraces. The Chaldean (“cal-DEE-in”) king Nebuchadnezzar II built this location, which was among the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. For 10 points, name this legendary green space in Babylon.
tossups.answer: Hanging Gardens of Babylon <NC, Ancient/Archaeology>

tossups.question: This social scientist agrees with Paul Ricœur’s (“ree-KURR’s”) criticism of his work as “Kantism without a transcendental subject,” but insists that it’s not really a criticism, in an “Overture” with a long digression on serialism in music. This social scientist claimed that the “principle of reciprocity” and the “incest taboo” were near-universal regulators of marriage in his “alliance theory,” which adapts an approach pioneered in linguistics by (*) Ferdinand de Saussure. In a third book, this anthropologist contrasts engineers and their “scientific mind” with people who build with what is at hand, bricoleurs (“bree-koh-LURRS”), who exhibit the title sort of mentality found among primitive peoples. “The Raw and the Cooked” and The Savage Mind are by, for 10 points, what French founder of structural anthropology?
tossups.answer: Claude Lévi-Strauss <WA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>

tossups.question: In 2006, Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Hollis Robbins released an “Annotated” version of this novel. This novel, whose author later defended its accuracy in “A Key to” it, is called “a very bad novel” for “its rejection of life… the denial of [its] beauty, dread, power” in an essay from Notes of a Native Son. This novel is referenced in the title of a collection that includes “Big Boy Leaves Home” and “Down by the Riverside,” written by (*) Richard Wright. George Aiken’s popular stage adaptation of this novel was used for many “shows” that often took the form of minstrel plays and used blackface. The quote “So this is the little lady who started this great war” was spoken by Abraham Lincoln regarding, for 10 points, what novel about “Life Among the Lowly,” an anti-slavery novel by Harriet Beecher Stowe?
tossups.answer: Uncle Tom’s Cabin [or Uncle Tom’s Cabin; or, Life Among the Lowly] <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: To solve integral equations, Fredholm generalized this function to operators of the form of the identity plus a trace-class operator. Because one is a regular value of this function, the Special Linear Group is a manifold. Solutions to a differential equation are linearly independent if there is a nonzero value for one of these functions called the Wronskian (“RON-skee-in”). For large inputs, this alternating (*) multilinear map can be computed using the Laplace expansion theorem, which requires finding cofactors and minors. Eigenvalues are computed by setting this function of the matrix “A minus lambda I” equal to zero and solving for lambda. A matrix A is singular if and only if this function of A is zero. For 10 points, name this quantity often expressed as “ad minus bc” for a two-by-two matrix.
tossups.answer: determinants <NC, Math>

tossups.question: Over one hundred men were massacred after rioting when a member of this tribe lost a horse race at Fort Fauntleroy. Three years after signing the Bear Springs Treaty, this tribe’s Chief Narbona was shot and killed during peace talks at Fort Wingate. Thousands of peach trees belonging to this tribe were destroyed in the Canyon de Chelly (“shay”) by Kit Carson’s troops. In the 1860s, General James Carleton forcibly removed members of this tribe to Fort Sumner in the Long (*) Walk to Bosque Redondo (“BO-skay ray-DOHN-doh”). After being raised on this tribe’s reservation, engineer Philip Johnston proposed that the US Marines use its language to stump World War II cryptographers by recruiting a group of twenty-nine “code-talkers.” For 10 points, name this Native American tribe whose namesake “Nation” is a reservation in the American southwest.
tossups.answer: Navajo [or Diné] <NC, US History>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: Objects named for this figure were frequently created during the Aurignacian (“or-ig-NAY-shin”) period and include a “black” one that was found at Dolni Vestonice (“DOHL-nee ves-toh-NEET-seh”). For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Venus figurines [accept Venuses or Venus of Willendorf, Hohle Fels, etc.]
Austria [accepte Österreich]
caves <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>
parts: Give this figure that names all those objects, the oldest of which was made from mammoth ivory in Hohle Fels (“HO-luh FELSE”). Another object named for this figure is distinguished by its large belly and acorn-like hairstyle.
The most famous Venus figurine was found in this country’s town of Willendorf (“VILL-en-dorf”). The proto-Celtic Hallstatt (“HALL-shtott”) culture is named for an archaeological site in this country.
The Venus of Hohle Fels was found in one of these places. Paintings of bulls are frequently found on the walls of these places, which include Lascaux (“lass-KO”) and Altamira.

bonuses.leadin: Neutrophils use enzyme NADPH oxidase to produce this ion to combat pathogens with their respiratory burst. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: superoxide [or O2 minus; accept superoxide dismutase; do not accept or prompt on “O2”]
hydrogen peroxide [or H2O2]
horseradish [accept Armoracia rusticana or Cochlearia armoracia] <RN, Biology: Genetics/Cell>
parts: Name this reactive radical ion. Mutations in another enzyme that dismutates this ion have been shown to cause Lou Gehrig’s disease.
Superoxide dismutase converts superoxide into this other molecule, which can itself decompose into two hydroxyl radicals. Catalase converts this molecule to water.
A peroxidase from this plant is used as a reporter enzyme in Western blots and ELISA (“ee-LIE-zuh”) assays. That enzyme from this plant turns TMB blue.

bonuses.leadin: The “Dedication” of this poetry collection is made out to the author’s friend Théophile Gautier (“tay-oh-FEEL goat-YAY”), whom it calls a “magician of letters.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Flowers of Evil [or Les fleurs du mal]
Charles Baudelaire

corpses [or cadavers or dead bodies or carcasses or charognes or morts; accept dead people; accept “A Carcass” or “Une charogne” or “The Joyous Corpse” or “Le mort joyeux”; prompt on bodies] <WA, Poetry>
parts: Name this poetry collection whose entry “The Litanies of Satan” repeatedly implores the title figure to “take pity on my long misery!”
This decadent 19th-century French poet wrote The Flowers of Evil.

A disturbing poem from The Flowers of Evil that sexualizes one of these objects describes watching it “blossom like a flower” in the summer while “black battalions” of creatures emerge from it. The speaker wishes to “sleep in oblivion like a shark” in a Baudelaire sonnet titled for a “joyous” one of these.

bonuses.leadin: This artist’s gigantic mural Paradise is one of the world’s largest paintings, at over 25 meters long, and decorates the main hall of the Doge’s Palace. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Tintoretto [or Jacopo Comin]
Bacchus AND Ariadne [accept Dionysus in place of “Bacchus”] (The other artist is Titian.)
The Last Supper <WA, Painting/Sculpture>
parts: Name this Venetian artist whose cycle about the patron saint of his city, Saint Mark, includes his paintings Saint Mark’s Body Brought to Venice and The Miracle of the Slave.

Tintoretto’s depiction of Venus and these two figures is widely regarded as a reference to Venice’s traditional “wedding to the sea” ceremony. In another Venetian artist’s painting titled for these two figures, a pair of cheetahs look out at the sea on the left and snakes strangle a man on the right.
Tintoretto’s less Venetian-themed works include two depictions of this scene, one of which oddly uses a diagonal angle for the central table. Leonardo’s version of this scene shows Judas whispering.

bonuses.leadin: A popular textbook used in and titled for this interdisciplinary field is by David Buss, much of whose research concerns the impact of choosing short-term versus long-term mating strategies. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: evolutionary psychology [or evo psych; prompt on psychology or evolution]
Steven Pinker
The Origin of Species [or On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life] <WA, Social Science: Psych>
parts: Name this field. Its founders included the husband-and-wife team John Tooby and Leda Cosmides (“KOZ-mid-eez”), who expounded a critique of the “standard social science model,” or SSSM, in their book The Adapted Mind.
This Harvard psychologist and linguist criticized the title concept from the SSSM in The Blank Slate. This author’s books for a popular audience include The Language Instinct.
Evolutionary psychology is ultimately rooted in this book by Charles Darwin, in which he propounded the theory of evolution by natural selection.

bonuses.leadin: An equation sets the differential of the so-called “PV” type of this quantity equal to negative pressure times differential volume. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: work
virtual [accept virtual work or virtual particles]
Rudolf Clausius <WA, Physics>
parts: Name this quantity that can be calculated as the spatial path integral of force, or sometimes more simply as “force times distance.”
D’Alembert (“dal-om-BAIR”) developed a principle named for this type of work. This adjective also describes instantaneously created particles whose lifetime is limited by the uncertainty principle.

Joule introduced the idea of mechanical work in 1845, around the same time as this German physicist developed the ideas put forth in “On the Moving Force of Heat.” A later paper by this scientist introduced the concept of entropy.

bonuses.leadin: In the context of valuing companies, this two-word phrase denotes potential value that a company may have above that of its assets and its goodwill. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: blue sky [or blue skies; accept blue sky research; prompt on sky]
Tim Berners-Lee [or TimBL]
FDA [or Food and Drug Administration] <WA, Other Academic>
parts: Give this two-word phrase that, in science, refers to basic research that is conducted without taking into account any practical application.

One major product of blue sky research was this British computer scientist’s research into communications for CERN, which led to the creation of hypertext. As a result, he is credited with inventing the World Wide Web.

About 80 percent of medicines approved by this US federal agency can be traced back to basic research, although it takes on average 31 years from when the research was conducted until this agency’s approval.

bonuses.leadin: Beatrice is slowly turned venomous by her scientist father in one of this author’s stories. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Nathaniel Hawthorne
staff [or walking stick or cane]
Herman Melville <AR, Short Fiction>
parts: Name this author who collected “Rappaccini’s Daughter” and “Young Goodman Brown” in Mosses from an Old Manse.

Early on, Young Goodman Brown meets an elderly man holding this creepy, snake-like object. After finding Faith’s pink ribbon, Goodman Brown uses this object to run extremely fast to the story’s concluding Satanic ritual.

This author called “Young Goodman Brown” as “deep as Dante” and not-so-subtly described how Hawthorne “dropped germinous seeds into [his] soul” in his review of Mosses from an Old Manse titled “Hawthorne and his Mosses.” He wrote The Piazza Tales.

bonuses.leadin: This book concludes by restating a declaration made in its opening paragraph, that “Whereof one cannot speak thereof one must be silent.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus [accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, Wittgenstein’s Tractatus or answers that indicate the Tractatus of Ludwig Wittgenstein; prompt on Tractatus]
Ludwig Wittgenstein
elementary propositions <WA, Phil/Thought>
parts: Name this work of analytic philosophy structured around seven major propositions. Many of its ideas were rejected in its author’s later major work, Philosophical Investigations.
The Tractatus and Philosophical Investigations are both by this Austrian-born philosopher and laid the foundations for much analytic philosophy.
According to the Tractatus, all complex propositions are truth-functions of these simpler sorts of propositions. Wittgenstein calls one of these propositions a “nexus” or “concatenation of names.”

bonuses.leadin: Name these contemporary film directors who have depicted sexual obsession, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: Steve McQueen
Lars von Trier (The films are Nymphomaniac and The House that Jack Built.)
Martin Scorsese (“scor-SAY-zee”) [or Martin Charles Scorsese] <RK, Other Arts: Film>
parts: Michael Fassbender played the sex addict Brandon, whose life is thrown out of balance by his sister’s return, in this British director’s film Shame. This man directed 12 Years a Slave.

In a lengthy erotic film by this director, Seligman’s accounts of fly-fishing parallel the sexual experiences of Joe, who is played by Charlotte Gainsbourg. The 2018 premiere of a film by this director about a serial killer led to several mass walkouts at Cannes (“can”).
Paul Schrader, who fictionalized the life of sex addict Bob Crane in his 2002 film Auto Focus, is better known for writing screenplays for films by this director, such as Taxi Driver and Raging Bull.

bonuses.leadin: In Helvering v. Davis, the Supreme Court held that the Social Security Act was constitutional under this clause. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: general welfare clause
Alexander Hamilton
Tenth Amendment <WA, US History>
parts: Name this clause from Article I, Section 8 of the US Constitution which states that Congress may tax and spend for debts, common defense, and for this clause’s namesake purpose.
A broad interpretation of the general welfare clause was put forth by this Founding Father, who claimed that it granted Congress plenary power to spend. He was the first US Secretary of the Treasury.

Opponents of the broad interpretation of the general welfare clause often cite this constitutional amendment, which concerns “powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution.” The Helvering ruling held that Social Security did not violate this amendment.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the evolution of modern plants, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: non-vascular plants
rhizoids [do not accept or prompt on “rhizomes”]
seeds <RR, Biology: Dev/Plant>
parts: Some of the earliest types of plants fall into this category, named for the lack of tracheary (“TRAY-kee-airy”) elements or other types of tissue to conduct water. They include bryophytes, liverworts, and hornworts.
Without vascular tissue, more ancient plants also lack proper root systems and instead use these root-like structures.
Modern plants produce these reproductive structures. Spermatophytes are plants that bear these structures containing the embryo, nutrients, and protection within a coat.

bonuses.leadin: The elderly painter Lorenzo refuses to sell or exhibit his self-portrait despite his family’s descent into poverty in a play from this country whose title parodies A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Philippines [or Republic of the Philippines; or Republika ng Pilipinas]
Catholicism [or Catholic Church; prompt on Christianity]
magical realism [or magic realism; or marvelous realism; or realismo mágico; or lo real maravilloso] (The unnamed novel is Isabel Allende’s The House of the Spirits.) <JM, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this country. A novelist and ophthalmologist called this country a “lost Eden” in a poem that he wrote while awaiting his execution titled “My Last Farewell.”

That author, José Rizal, reacted to the abuse by Spanish priests of this religion in novels like Noli Me Tángere (“no-lee may TAHN-gay-ray”). Two Portuguese missionaries of this religion travel to Japan in Shūsaku Endō’s Silence.

Nick Joaquin, the author of A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, contributed to this style with stories like “May Day Eve.” Alejo Carpentier’s (“ah-LAY-ho car-pen-tee-AIR’s”) preface to The Kingdom of This World coined the term for this style, which was used for a novel set at the hacienda Las Tres Marías.

bonuses.leadin: This leader promoted the idea of the mission civilisatrice (“meese-YAWN see-vee-lee-sa-TREESE”) in a speech that justified a massive colonial expansion by saying “the higher races have a right over the lower ones.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Jules Ferry [accept Jules Ferry laws]
Georges Clemenceau [or Georges Eugene Benjamin Clemenceau]
Treaty of Versailles <ML, European History>
parts: Name this leader who annexed Tunisia, Madagascar, North Vietnam, and Congo for France. He is more famous for a law that fully secularized the French education system.
This other French prime minister was a leading opponent of Ferry’s colonial policy. He was nicknamed “The Tiger,” and his magazine L’Aurore (“lo-ROR”) published Émile Zola’s J’Accuse.
Georges Clemenceau was the French representative of the “Big Four” during negotiations of this treaty. This treaty ended World War I.

bonuses.leadin: While recovering from blindness, Guido (“GWEE-doh”) von List claimed to have had a vision of 18 “secret” examples of these letters that he believed were used by ancient Aryan priest-kings. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: runes [or runic letters; or runic alphabet; or futhark]
Heimdall
Thule [accept Thule Society or Thule-Gesellschaft] <WA, Myths/Legends>
parts: Name these letters used by Vikings and other early Germanic peoples, some of whom also believed that they could be used to cast spells.
In the Poetic Edda, this god appears under his name of Ríg (“reeg”) and teaches runes to his son Jarl (“yarl”). This Norse god has golden hair, golden teeth, a golden horse, and a golden horn.

The study of runic magic was revived in the 20th century by an occultist organization named for this place that advocated Ariosophy and, unsurprisingly, was full of Nazi sympathizers. This mythical land of the far north is described in Latin and Greek literature.

bonuses.leadin: Heraclius II’s declaration of an independent kingdom led to a war over his realm between these two empires. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Russian Empire AND Persia [accept Qajar in place of “Persia”; do not accept or prompt on “Soviet Union” in place of “Russia”; do not accept or prompt on “Iran” or “Safavid Empire” in place of “Persia”]
Georgia [accept Sakartvelo]
United States of America [or USA; or America] <JM, World History>
parts: Name these two empires, one of which annexed the regions of Karabagh, Imeretia, and Shirvan from the other. These two empires signed the Treaty of Gulistan.
Heraclius II ruled this kingdom as part of its long-serving Bagrationi (“ba-gra-tee-OWN-ee”) royal house. This kingdom’s earlier rulers included David the Builder and Queen Tamar.

William Morgan Shuster, a banker from this country who was appointed as Persia’s finance minister, attacked Anglo-Russian influence in his book The Strangling of Persia. This country would later have its citizens abducted during a 1979 hostage crisis in Iran.

bonuses.leadin: The Europa Editions version of this series has book covers whose kitschy appearances have drawn comparisons to “chick-lit” art. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Neapolitan Novels [or Neapolitan Quartet]
mafia [or mob; or crime family; accept Cosa Nostra]
New York City [or NYC; accept The New York Review of Books or NYREV or NYRB] <ML, Long Fiction>
parts: Name this four-part series translated from Italian by Ann Goldstein. Its first entry begins with the disappearance of the protagonist’s “brilliant friend,” Lila Cerullo.

A major antagonizing force throughout Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan Novels is the Solara family, who head one of these organizations. Mario Puzo’s novel The Godfather centers on one of these organizations.

The pseudonymous Elena Ferrante was outed as translator Anita Raja in Claudio Gatti’s article printed in a magazine based in this city. That “Review of Books” based in this city publishes a celebrated line of “Classics.”

bonuses.leadin: A piece before this opera’s first act was published separately with the title “Dawn” as part of the Four Sea Interludes. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Peter Grimes
Benjamin Britten
mystery plays [or miracle plays; prompt on plays or drama; do not accept or prompt on “mummer’s plays” or “morality plays”] <WA, Classical/Opera>
parts: Name this opera in which the death of the apprentice John at sea is represented by an eerie tuba solo. At its end, the title sailor is implied to have died by sinking his own ship, which Auntie dismisses as “one of these rumors.”
Peter Grimes is an opera by this British composer of A Young Person’s Guide to the Orchestra.

Britten’s opera Noye’s Fludde (“noise flood”), meant to be performed by young people and amateurs, is adapted from a cycle of these performances that originated in Chester. These performances were accompanied by antiphonal (“an-TIFF-uh-null”) song, and many of them were created in the 16th century by the Wakefield Master.

bonuses.leadin: Examples of these systems west of the Continental Divide typically have the Pacific Ocean as their ultimate outlet. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: river basin [or drainage basin or catchment basin; or watershed; or catchment area; or impluvium; prompt on drainage area]
ephemeral streams [prompt on arroyos or wadis]
GIS [or geographic information systems; accept ArcGIS; prompt on databases or information systems] <WA, Earth Science>
parts: Give this term for the entire area drained by a river. These areas may be endorheic (“en-doh-REE-ick”) if they do not drain to an ocean.

Some of the most marginal components of a river basin are streams denoted by this adjective, which only flow briefly after rainfall. These sorts of streams are contrasted with perennial streams, which always flow, and intermittent streams, which flow for a few months of the year.

The flows of ephemeral streams are tracked using data stored in these systems, which collect, analyze, and display data about various spaces on the Earth. Esri developed the “Arc” example of these systems.

bonuses.leadin: This author’s primary religious inspiration was the “Simple Contemplation” outlined by Ludolph of Saxony in the latter’s De Vita Christi. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Ignatius of Loyola [or Ignacio de Loyola or Ignazio Loiolakoa; prompt on Ignatius or Loyola]
Jesuits [or Iesuitae or Society of Jesus or Societas Iesu; prompt on SJ]
Saint John of the Cross [or San Juan de la Cruz; prompt on John] <WA, Religion>
parts: Name this author who wrote a set of devotional prayers and meditations meant to be performed over a period of four weeks in his Spiritual Exercises.
Ignatius of Loyola founded this religious order whose members conducted extensive missionary and education work in Asia and the Americas. Pope Francis is the first Pope from this order.

This other 16th-century Spanish clergyman wrote the treatise Ascent of Mount Carmel, which instructs people how to achieve mystical union with Christ and begins with his poem “Dark Night of the Soul.”
